timeline.bodyText: I think we can move this in a follow up into either fetchRewrite itself or some utils or make it top-level, because we will need this for other operators as well.
timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.message: Make fetch rewrite rule propagate through the whole sub-tree

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * We can in a first phase fetch the values for [_fetchid, a],

timeline.author: seut
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -48,6 +48,35 @@ import java.util.Map; import java.util.function.Function; +/** + *

+ * The fetch operator represents a 2 phase execution that is used to reduce value look-ups. + *

+ * + * For example: + * + * 
+ *     Limit[10]
+ *      └ OrderBy [a]
+ *        └ Collect [a, b, c]
+ *
+ * + * Would fetch the values for all columns ([a, b, c]) {@code 10 * num_nodes} times. + * With the fetch operator: + * + * 
+ *     Fetch [a, b, c]
+ *      └ Limit [10]
+ *        └ OrderBy [a]
+ *          └ Collect [_fetchid, a]
+ *
+ * + * We can in a first phase fetch the values for [_fetchid, a],

timeline.author: seut
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -149,6 +149,40 @@ default boolean preferShardProjections() {
      */
     LogicalPlan pruneOutputsExcept(Collection<Symbol> outputsToKeep);
 
+    /**
+     * Rewrite an operator and its children to utilize a "query-then-fetch" approach.
+     * See {@link Fetch} for an explanation of query-then-fetch.
+     * <pre>
+     * This must propagate if possible. Example:
+     *
+     *     Limit[10]            // calls source.rewriteToFetch
+     *      └ Order [a ASC]     // should call source.rewriteToFetch
+     *        └ Collect [x, a, b]
+     *
+     * This results in:
+     *
+     *      Fetch[x, a, b]
+     *       └ Limit[10]
+     *         └ Order [a ASC]
+     *           └ Collect [_fetchid, a]
+     *
+     * Note that propagation only needs to happen if all operators can forward the `_fetchid`. Consider the following:
+     *
+     *      Limit[10]
+     *        └ HashAggregate[min(x), min(y)]
+     *          └ Limit[5]
+     *            └ Collect [x, y]
+     *
+     * In this case a call on `HashAggregate.rewriteToFetch` can return `null` to indicate that there is nothing to fetch,
+     * because `HashAggregate` needs all columns produce its result.

timeline.author: seut

timeline.bodyText: Looks like there is no LogicalPlan test for this optimization, maybe worth creating one?
timeline.author: seut

timeline.message: Enable query-then-fetch for Limit → Order → Collect
